https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The study of the role of processes and compounds that are derived from living or once-living organisms, i.e. the study of the transformation undergone by organic matter of all types, whether of biological or man-made origin, in the Earth System. The transformations involved vary from those mediated by biological processes involved in the production of living tissue and the operation of food-chains, to those controlled by temperature and pressure at depth in the crust. Photochemical processes in the atmosphere and hydrosphere can also be important in controlling the environmental behaviour of some organic compounds.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value:
From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from: 
Killops, SD and Killops, VJ 2013, Introduction to Organic Geochemistry: John Wiley & Sons, 408p.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: The study of the role of processes and compounds that are derived from living or once-living organisms, i.e. the study of the transformation undergone by organic matter of all types, whether of biological or man-made origin, in the Earth System. The transformations involved vary from those mediated by biological processes involved in the production of living tissue and the operation of food-chains, to those controlled by temperature and pressure at depth in the crust. Photochemical processes in the atmosphere and hydrosphere can also be important in controlling the environmental behaviour of some organic compounds.

The characterization of the physical properties and elemental analysis of oil and gas, used to interpret the type of source rock and correlate to a source rock, determine the thermal maturity of the oil and gas (and hence the maturity of the source rock), potential dating of the source rock, and compare oil and gas composition between different fields or within a field.
The evaluation of the lithological sources of hydrocarbons, i.e. those rocks which contain organic matter and are (or have been) generating and/or expelling hydrocarbons to form accumulations.
